skill.name: metabolomics-workbench-database
skill.description: Access NIH Metabolomics Workbench via REST API (4,200+ studies). Query metabolites, RefMet nomenclature, MS/NMR data, m/z searches, study metadata, for metabolomics and biomarker discovery.
skill.summary: Access NIH Metabolomics Workbench via REST API (4,200+ studies). Query metabolites, RefMet nomenclat...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with API documentation. No executable code, scripts, network calls, file system access, or environment variable reads. This skill provides instructions for using the NIH Metabolomics Workbench REST API.

content.value_statement: Search thousands of metabolomics studies and metabolite data from the NIH database. Access standardized nomenclature, mass spectrometry data, and study metadata for biomarker discovery and metabolic research.
actual_capabilities: Query metabolite structures by PubChem CID, InChI Key, KEGG ID, HMDB ID
Search 4,200+ metabolomics studies by metabolite, institute, or investigator
Standardize metabolite names using RefMet nomenclature database
Perform m/z searches for mass spectrometry compound identification
Filter studies by analytical platform, species, sample source, and disease
Access gene and protein data linked to metabolic pathways
limitations: Requires internet connection to access NIH API endpoints
Does not perform offline analysis of local metabolomics data
Rate limits may apply for high-volume automated queries
Limited to publicly available data in Metabolomics Workbench

use_cases.title: Identify metabolites from MS data
use_cases.description: Search compound databases by m/z values to identify unknown metabolites from mass spectrometry experiments.

use_cases.title: Find disease biomarker studies
use_cases.description: Filter metabolomics studies by disease type, sample source, and analytical method for biomarker research.

use_cases.title: Standardize compound names
use_cases.description: Use RefMet to convert common metabolite names to standardized nomenclature for consistent reporting.

prompt_templates.title: Basic metabolite search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find studies in Metabolomics Workbench containing measurements of [metabolite_name]

prompt_templates.title: Compound identification
prompt_templates.scenario: Identify compounds from mass spec data
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for compounds with m/z value of [mz_value] using [adduct_type] adduct and tolerance of [tolerance] Da

prompt_templates.title: Disease study search
prompt_templates.scenario: Find studies for a specific disease
prompt_templates.prompt: Find human blood studies on [disease_name] using LC-MS positive mode in Metabolomics Workbench

prompt_templates.title: Complete workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Standardize the metabolite name [metabolite], find all related studies, retrieve experimental data from the most relevant study, and identify compounds from my MS data with m/z of [mz_value]

output_examples.input: Find studies containing measurements of glucose in Metabolomics Workbench
output: Top studies: ST000001 (Diabetes study), ST000002 (Metabolic syndrome), ST000003 (Blood glucose regulation)
First study: 156 metabolites measured using LC-MS positive mode
Glucose registry number: 1590 in Metabolomics Workbench

best_practices: Always standardize metabolite names through RefMet before searching to ensure consistent nomenclature
Use appropriate ion adduct types for your analytical method (M+H for positive ESI, M-H for negative ESI)
Set reasonable mass tolerance values based on your instrument resolution (0.5 Da for low-res, 0.01 Da for high-res MS)
anti_patterns: Using inconsistent metabolite names across queries without standardization
Ignoring study metadata when selecting datasets for analysis
Failing to cross-reference metabolite identifiers across multiple databases

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: The skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Install via npx claude-code-templates@latest --skill metabolomics-workbench-database.

faq.question: How many studies are available?
faq.answer: Over 4,200 processed studies with 3,790+ publicly available. Access study metadata, experimental data, and metabolite lists.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with analysis pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the REST API endpoints with Python requests, the mwtab Python package, or R metabolomicsWorkbenchR package.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only provides API documentation. No data is stored or transmitted. All requests go directly to NIH servers.

faq.question: Why are my queries returning no results?
faq.answer: Check spelling of metabolite names, use RefMet standardization, verify study filters are not too restrictive, or try broader search terms.

faq.question: How does this compare to PubChem or HMDB?
faq.answer: Metabolomics Workbench focuses on experimental metabolomics studies. PubChem and HMDB provide broader compound databases with more structural information.
